entry.title: Embedded Analytics for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 - List of Available Tables Reporting & Dashboard
entry.content:
SAP Sales & Service Cloud Version 2 (V2) introduces a modernized approach to analytics by embedding SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) directly into the platform. This integration provides powerful reporting and dashboard capabilities without relying on external tools, enabling real-time insights and advanced visualization options.

Note :
Embedded Analytics provided in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 is based on the embedded edition of SAP Analytics Cloud (eSAC). It is not the full version of SAP Analytics Cloud and therefore offers a limited set of functionalities compared to the standalone SAC solution.

What is Embedded Analytics in V2?

Unlike previous versions, V2 does not have native analytics. Instead, it leverages SAP Analytics Cloud, embedded edition (eSAC) as the single analytics engine across SAP solutions. This ensures:

  • Unified reporting experience across Sales and Service processes.
  • Real-time data analysis using standard V2 data sources.
  • Advanced visualization options like charts, tables, KPIs, and interactive dashboards.

Key Features

  • Design Stories Workcenter for administrators to create dashboards.
  • Analysis Workcenter for end-users to view and interact with stories.
  • Role-based access for personalized reporting.
  • Calculated Columns & Filters for custom metrics.
  • Single Sign-On (SSO) for secure access to eSAC

Available Data Sources & Tables

Embedded SAC uses the same standard data sources as native Business Analytics in v2. These include:

  • Opportunity Data (Forecast vs. Actuals)
  • Account & Contact Information
  • Activity & Interaction Logs
  • Service Tickets / Cases (Status, Escalation, Source Channels)
  • Sales Orders & Quotes
  • Lead Management Data
  • Product & Pricing Tables

Each data source can be extended with:

  • Filters (e.g., by region, status, time frame)
  • Calculated Columns (e.g., revenue variance, SLA compliance)
  • Aggregations for KPIs.

Reporting & Dashboard Capabilities

With embedded SAC, you can:

  • Build Stories combining charts, tables, and text.
  • Create Numeric Charts for KPIs like Open Tickets or Revenue.
  • Use Color Coding & Conditional Formatting for better insights.
  • Enable Drill-down Analysis for detailed exploration.
  • Share dashboards securely across teams

Benefits for Sales & Service Teams

  • Sales Managers can track pipeline health, forecast accuracy, and order conversion.
  • Service Managers can monitor ticket resolution times, escalation trends, and customer satisfaction.
  • Executives get consolidated dashboards for strategic decision-making.

entry.title: Authorization setup for SAC Live Model from S4 ABAP CDS Views
entry.content:
Purpose of this document

Implementing robust authorization mechanisms is crucial when delivering SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) reports based on live connections to S/4HANA, especially when sourcing data from ABAP CDS views.

In SAC, live data connections to S/4HANA allow users to analyze real-time business data. When reports are built on ABAP CDS views, it is essential to ensure that data-level authorization is enforced, reflecting underlying S/4HANA security policies. This ensures sensitive data remains accessible only to authorized users.

 

Introductions

Before configuring connection-specific authorizations, it’s essential to understand how SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) secures access. SAC uses users, roles, teams, and business catalogs to control what each user can see or do, following the principle of least privilege. Administrators assign roles and teams, manage permissions, and define who can view or edit data. In most modern landscapes, SAC is integrated with corporate identity providers via SAML or OAuth, enabling SSO and automated role/user provisioning.

SAC provides two main mechanisms for data security: Model Data Privacy, which defines read/write permissions for entire models using conditions or expressions, and Data Access Control, which restricts access at the dimension level (such as plant or region) within a model. These settings ensure users only see data relevant to them.

With this foundation, readers are ready to follow the step-by-step authorization setup for import and live models—whether sourced from S/4HANA, HANA Calculation Views, or SAP Datasphere.

 

Authorization Setup Steps

Pre-requisites, you already have CDS view type consumption created for SAC Live Model on top of which SAC Model and Story is available for authorization setup.

 

Step 1: Enabling CDS views for authorization check

  1. Identify the CDS view (consumption type) on which authorization is required. Example. ZC_SALES
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
  • The access conditions are evaluated implicitly in each ABAP SQL read. Based on @AccessControl.authorizationCheck 
  • CHECK (Default value)
  • NOT_REQUIRED
  • NOT_ALLOWED
  • If access control is enabled, only that data is read that meets the access conditions. 

2. Identify CDS view (cube type) on which consumption CDS view is created. Example, ZI_SALES_CUBE, Access control CDS views will be created on CUBE of final consumption view.

For this authorization setup we will try to apply authorization for three fields in CDS which are available in Consumption and Cube type CDS views. Two fields via PFCG authorization and 3rd field by assigning values directly in DCL.

  • Customer
  • Department
  • Company Code

 

Step 2: Creating Authorization fields and authorization objects required

  1. Goto transaction SU20, click on Create Authorization field as shown below,

2. Fill in details, Authorization Field Name, Package, Data element and click save. Example, ZAOSALES01(Authorization field for Sales Reporting)

3. Goto transaction SU21, click on Create Authorization Object as shown below,

4. Fill in details, Authorization Object Name, Description, Authorization Class (create if not available for use) and click save. Example, ZAFCUST (Customer) , ZAFDEPT (Department)

 

Step 3: Creating Access Control Views (DCL)

  1. In your ABAP project, select the relevant package node in the Project Explorer.
  2. Open the context menu and choose New  Other ABAP Repository Object  Core Data Services  Access Control.
  3. In addition to the Project and Package, enter the Name and the Description for the access control to be created.

 

[Optional:] If you want to create an access control for a specific CDS entity, enter the relevant entity name as the Protected Entity.

Note: You can only protect CDS entities.

4. Choose Next. Assign a transport request. Choose Next.

5. Determine if you want to use a template for the access control. SAP offers example templates for access controls. The template provides you with example coding for you to modify. If you do not use a template, the tool creates an empty access control for you to code.

6. Choose Finish.

 

Results

In the selected package, AS ABAP creates an inactive version of an access control and stores it in the ABAP Repository. In the Project Explorer, the new access control is added to the Access Controls folder of the corresponding package node. As a result of this procedure, the access control editor opens. Define the role for the CDS entity.

 

Example

The following role grants access to entries of the ZI_SALES_CUBE CDS entity, which meet the following conditions:

  • The ‘Customer’ of the entry has the same value as is assigned to the user through the PFCG authorization object ZAOSALES01 in the respective authorization field ZAFCUST for ‘Customer’ and ZAFDEPT for ‘Department’ field.
  • The ‘CompanyCode’ of the entry has the constant value ‘1000’ assigned to view directly. This is constant application of           can be done directly in role.

The @MappingRole annotation must have the value true, so this role is assigned to all users in the system. The value false is not supported.

@EndUserText.label: 'Show only sales data where in customer and department for company code ‘1000’'
	@MappingRole: true
	define role ZR_SALES001 {
    	grant select on ZI_SALES_CUBE
        where ( Customer, Department) = aspect pfcg_auth( ZAOSALES01, ZAFCUST, ZAFDEPT) AND CompanyCode ='1000';  
    }

Step 4: Creating PFCG Roles

  1. Go to transaction PFCG, create a single role.
  2. Provide role description, go to authorization tab, edit authorization.
  3. Add authorization manually, and add your custom authorization object create in above step.
  4. Add values manually against authorization fields.
  5. Click on generate profile and save role.

 

Step 5: Assigning roles to user

  1. Once the roles are created, assign custom roles to test user.
  2. Assing standard RFC and display access roles for Eclipse and SAC as required.
  3. Test SAC reports using multiple user accounts to ensure that row-level and organizational-level restrictions are respected.
  4. Validate that unauthorized data remains hidden, in line with S/4HANA role assignments and DCL rules.

 

More on CDS Data Control Language (DCL)

It is the authorization layer used in ABAP CDS to restrict what data a user can see when accessing a CDS view. Access rules defined by DCL are joined by a logical “OR”. It is advisable to use one CDS rule for access control.

Types of CDS authorization rules:

  1. Conditional Rule
  2. Grant Rule
  3. Inherited Rule

 

Conditional Rule

What it does

  • Applies authorization only if a condition is met.
  • The rule restricts data based on values from an authorization object IF the condition evaluates to true.

Syntax Example             

@EndUserText.label: 'Example Access Role’
	@MappingRole: true
	define role my_role {
    	grant select on my_cds_view
        where ( field1, field2) = aspect pfcg_auth( my_auth_object, auth_field1, auth_field2);
    }

Combining two access rules via COMBINATION MODE

This can be used to change the combining condition of two access rules. COMBINATION MODE uses “OR” and “AND” conditions.

@EndUserText.label: 'Example Access Role’
@MappingRole: true
define role my_role {
    grant select on my_cds_view
        where ( field1 ) = aspect pfcg_auth( my_auth_object, auth_field1)
};
    grant select on my_cds_view
    combination mode and 
        where ( field2) = aspect pfcg_auth( my_auth_object, auth_field2)
};

  • The addition can be used for a maximum of one access rule for a CDS entity.
  • This addition also disables existing full access rules for a CDS entity.

 

Grant Rule

What it does:

  • Explicitly grants authorization to access a CDS entity. You can remove where condition and provide access to complete CDS view.
  • To control which fields are checked and what data values a user can access.

Syntax Example:

  1. Providing complete CDS access
@EndUserText.label: 'Example Access Role’
@MappingRole: true
define role my_role {
    grant select on my_cds_view
};

2. Proving access based on session variables

@EndUserText.label: 'Example Access Role’
@MappingRole: true
define role my_role {
    grant select on my_cds_view
        where salesorg = $session.<session_variable>
    };

 

Inherited Rule

What it does:

  • Allows a view to inherit authorization behaviour from another CDS view.
  • Used when a CDS view is based on another CDS view that already has authorization rules.

Syntax Example:

@EndUserText.label: 'Example Access Role’
@MappingRole: true
define role my_role {
     grant select on my_cds_view
     inherit my_other_role
};

This is used when we a CDS on top of which other reports/views are derived. The main CDS  has DCL on same required fields, we can inherit the access from existing DCL.

 

Recommendations and Best Practices

  1. Always leverage SAML-based SSO for real-time enforcement of authorizations from S/4HANA to SAC.
  2. Maintain clear documentation of all CDS-related authorization objects and DCL roles for compliance.
  3. Regularly review role assignments and authorization configurations as business requirements evolve.

 

Conclusion

With live SAC reports built on S/4HANA CDS views, user authorizations are seamlessly enforced by leveraging CDS access control and direct role assignments. This approach ensures business data is protected, compliant, and accessible only to those with the requisite permissions.

entry.title: Contribution Margin Forecast with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
MANAGEMENT SUMMARY

This blog demonstrates how SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) can be used to implement a contribution margin forecast, which serves companies as a substantial controlling tool to steer financial results in the short- and medium-term. Combining SAC Planning with Datasphere (“Seamless Planning”) allows for (near) real-time usage of actual data from SAP BW to extrapolate the variable cost component of the contribution margin, while SAC Planning is used to forecast the revenue component and report on the resulting KPIs.  The combination of the actual and planning data happens without the need for redundant data replication. Furthermore, this blog will briefly touch on how BDC can be leveraged to enhance this use case through a comprehensive path for BW modernization, the re-use of SAP-managed data products, and the application of advanced machine learning methods for forecasting.

RECAP

Before continue reading it is recommended to familiarize with the following preceding blog posts to properly understand the fundamentals:  

  • The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering puts this blog post into perspective of a comprehensive blog series that aims to demonstrate the business value add of SAP BDC.
  • Real-time steering with LIVE planning uncovers the "Seamless Planning" paradigm (which is the key enabler for below-described use case) and illustrates a practical end-to-end use case that leverages External Live Versions, our latest innovation in context of Seamless Planning.

MOTIVATION AND USE CASE

The motivation of this blog is to demonstrate a tangible implementation example for how BDC can be leveraged to enable effective and efficient business steering. The demonstrated use case is a contribution margin forecast which estimates future revenues and variable costs, calculating expected contribution margins over time. The contribution margin is particularly relevant for financial steering because fixed costs are, by definition, largely unchangeable in the short- and medium-term. Therefore, if a company aspires to impact financial results, management’s primary focus and opportunity for action resides in maximizing the contribution margin. In essence, the contribution margin is calculated by subtracting variable costs from revenues, with the remainder – that is, the contribution margin – available to cover fixed costs. The levers that management can actively influence on a regular basis are:

Picture 1: Calculation schema for Contribution Margin

Such a contribution margin forecast can be implemented in an innovative fashion leveraging the Seamless Planning capability within BDC as explained in the following paragraph.

IMPLEMENTATION

Considering the above-described contribution margin levers, we are using the following BDC components for the corresponding implementation.

A SAC Story on top of a SAC Planning model is used to enter sales volume forecast and pricing assumptions (1). Upon publishing (2) the forecasted values (volumes, prices) are directly persisted within Datasphere (“Seamless Planning”).

Picture 2: SAC frontend for revenue forecastDatasphere is used to acquire and model total actual variable costs and sales volumes based on SAP BW in our example (3) (or any other compatible and relevant source system). Note that actual sales volumes are acquired to allow the calculation of volume-weighted actual variable costs per unit in a later step. A union view (4) within Datasphere combines the forecasted sales volumes and prices (as provided via the SAC Planning frontend) with the actual sales volumes and variable costs (as acquired from SAP BW).

Picture 3: Data lineage within Datasphere

In an Analytic Model (5) on top of the union view the relevant KPIs consisting of both forecast and actual data are calculated:

Forecasted revenues: Restricted measures filter on forecasted volumes and prices originating from the SAC planning model. A calculated measure multiplies these two measures to derive the forecasted revenue [forecasted revenues = forecasted sales volumes * price assumption].

Extrapolated variable costs: Restricted measures filter on actual volumes and total manufacturing costs originating from SAP BW. These measures are cumulated over the actual time horizon as selected per prompt (6). A calculated measure divides cumulated costs by cumulated volumes to derive the volume-weighted average costs per unit [weighted-average costs per unit = cumulated actual costs/cumulated actual sales volumes]. Note that this measure is kept constant over the time dimension to allow applicability to any forecast months (see below).

Expected contribution margin: A calculated measure extrapolates the actual variable costs by multiplying the volume-weighted actuals costs per unit (see above) with the forecasted sales volumes [extrapolated variable costs = weighted-average actuals costs per unit * forecasted sales volumes]. A calculated measure subtracts extrapolated variable costs from forecasted revenues to finally derive the contribution margin [contribution margin forecast = forecasted revenues -  extrapolated variable costs].

Picture 4: Analytic Model within Datasphere A SAC Story on top the Analytic Model is used to steer the prompt for the weighted-average actual variable costs (6) and display the results -- that is, the weighted-average variable costs (left chart) and the derived contribution margin (right table) (7).

Picture 5: SAC frontend for analysis The following diagram summarizes the architecture and data flow at a glance.

Picture 6: Seamless Planning architecture

It is now worthwhile looking at the unique highlights of the above-described setup. First, Seamless Planning within BDC combines "best of both worlds": SAC planning and reporting capabilities with Datasphere ETL and modeling capabilities. Second, SAC planning model entries are directly exposed within Datasphere upon publishing without the need for redundant data replication. Third, it would be generally feasible to access the actual variable costs virtually (as opposed to replicated), thus combining planning with actual data in real-time. However, note that regular snapshots (near real-time) of the actual data can be required for high-performant dashboards. Forth, the prompt to dynamically steer the time range for the weighted-average actual variable costs allows end users to sort of “smoothen” the data over time (when choosing a longer range) versus emphasizing more recent months to reflect latest changes in cost structures etc. Lastly, given the completely automated retrieval of the variable costs part of the calculation, end users only need to manually update the expected sales volumes and price assumptions. This allows for a fast forecast process with a high frequency (e.g., monthly rolling forecast) which is highly relevant in today’s dynamic market environment.

POSSIBLE ENHANCEMENTS

In the above-described implementation setup actual data is being acquired from an SAP BW system via standard data acquisition means in Datasphere (remote tables, real-time replication, etc.). However, for SAP BW systems (both BW/4 and on HANA) BDC opens up the path for comprehensive BW modernization through means of the Data Product Generator (please see this blog for further details).

Furthermore, the use case could be enriched with SAP-managed data products derived from an S/4 PCE system as part of a BDC formation. For instance, if the contribution margin forecast should be integrated into a broader plan/actual reporting solution, the relevant actuals could be built upon SAP-managed data products serving as significant accelerators given that the complete data orchestration is handled by SAP. You could directly start modeling within Datasphere and combine the forecast data with the actual data based on the SAP-managed data products. A detailed blog discussing how you can leverage data products in the context of planning will follow.

Finally, for more advanced forecasting techniques you could leverage SAP Databricks as part of the BDC formation. Imagine that instead of the manually provided sales volume forecast as in the above example you would generate such a forecast by means of statistical methods such as time series forecasting.

Picture 7: Enhancement options with BDC

SUMMARY AND CALL TO ACTION

A contribution margin forecast allows companies to proactively steer financial results and can therefore be considered a crucial controlling instrument. SAP BDC enables an innovative implementation approach with clear benefits such as rapid, high-frequency forecasts through automated calculation of variable costs and replication-free, (near) real time combination of actual and planning data. Besides that, SAP BDC opens up the path for comprehensive BW modernization, thus allowing you to follow parallel streams: Implementation of innovative use cases while modernizing your SAP BW.  Sounds like a plan to you? Please reach out to your SAP representative and register for your SAP BDC Discovery Workshop!

entry.title: BW vs. Datasphere (DSP) & SAC
entry.content:
From a functional and development perspective, SAP BW and the combination of Datasphere (DSP) and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) represent two different generations of SAP’s data & analytics stack.

  • BW is feature‑rich and comes with many out‑of‑the‑box capabilities: tightly integrated data warehousing, mature modeling, and predefined mechanisms for enhancements and reporting.
  • DSP/SAC provides a leaner programming and configuration set, which often requires a “do‑it‑yourself” approach: more scripting, more custom logic, and more architectural decisions on the customer side.

However, DSP/SAC are actively and rapidly evolving. Each release brings new features—and sometimes new issues, especially in SAC—but the overall trajectory clearly indicates that DSP/SAC are the strategic future. Over the long term, the flexibility, cloud‑native approach, and continuous innovation of DSP & SAC are expected to outgrow and eventually surpass BW in capability and relevance.

How-To implement BW functionality in DSP/SAC

Architecture DSP https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-architecture-and-security-concept/ba-p/13702030

BW Security like in DSP/SAC https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/bw-like-authorizations-in-datasphere-dsp/ba-p/14153918

Generic-like extraction into DSP https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-delta-extraction/ba-p/13699391

BW to DSP extraction using ODP https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-bw-odp-delta-via-replication-flow/ba-p/13739830

BW BEx User/Customer Exit https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/how-to-build-bw-user-customer-exits-in-datasphere-dsp-sac/ba-p/14290016#M176749

DSP and SAC Versioning & Backup and Restore https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/datasphere-dsp-and-sac-data-and-metadata-versioning-backup-and-restore/ba-p/14291938#M176814

entry.title: How-To build BW BEx User/Customer Exits in Datasphere (DSP) / SAC
entry.content:
Basic:

In traditional SAP BW, User/Customer Exits allow for centrally managed code that applies to all BEx queries. An efficient, object-oriented approach. This functionality can be built via SAC's Composite Widgets (CW). The main / common functions such as ISO-week, Fiscal YearPeriod, Project specific functions, can be placed into a single / multiple CWs. These CWs will be added to Stories and the Stories can use the CWs – Interfaces (Public-like Methods). CWs use also own functions (Private-like Methods). This approach allows to have all the functions in one place.

 

Use cases:

This solution can be used to centralize and standardize various functions across multiple SAC stories, including:

  • A universal on/off switch for JavaScript logging. Logs are critical for troubleshooting, but also slow down the processing a bit and can provide unwanted details to end-users.
  • A custom function to calculate the ISO Week (not supported by default in SAC optimized stories).
  • Automatic calculation of the current fiscal period based on the current date.
  • A global "maintenance switch" to manage functionalities during version rollouts. Possible to route to an Out-Of-Order Story.
  • Displaying the data loading status from Datasphere.

 

How-To:

  • Create a composite (e.g. COMMON_FUNCTIONS) and move common JavaScript and functions from individual stories into this composite.
  • Expose functionality via interfaces (public) and keep helper logic as Functions (private methods) inside the composite.
  • Add the composite to each required story/page via drag & drop, hide it at design/runtime, and call its interfaces as if they were local story functions.
  • For configuration/switches (similar to TVARVC/P-tables), use SAC acquired models—optionally loaded from DSP via OData—for better performance than live connections.
  • Be aware of library limits inside composites (e.g. Application.getUser()), and pass required context (user, filters, etc.) from the story into the composite.

Possible only with SAC (native or seamless) planning:

Direct write-back from a Story (f.e. last used prompt). This part is not covered as planning is usually limited in SAC due to extra licensing as in BW/4.

 

Main blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/bw-vs-datasphere-dsp-amp-sac/ba-p/14289847
