entry.title: Low-Control Filtering in SAP Analytics Cloud (BW Live) Using Measure Variables with Text Input Field
entry.content:
Introduction

This analysis is designed to study executed project data and understand the relationship between order value and profitability.
By grouping completed projects into order value ranges, the model identifies where projects have resulted in profit or loss.
This helps users search, compare, and learn from past executions and use those insights while preparing new quotations and cost estimates.
The objective is to support better pricing decisions, risk identification, and margin improvement using real historical data.

Business Scenario

Users want to:

- Enter minimum and maximum cost values

- Apply them instantly to BW Live data

- Feed BW variable through Text Input fields as million errors to avoids incorrect number of zerso

Variable Design (Confidential Names)

Variable 1: Base Cost – Minimum (Million EUR)

Variable 2: Base Cost – Maximum (Million EUR)

Variable 3: Deviation – Minimum (Million EUR)

Variable 4: Deviation – Maximum (Million EUR)

Story Setup

Widgets used:

- Four Text Input fields

- One main BW Live table

- One helper table for filtering logic

Core Logic

  1. Read values from Text Input fields
  2. Convert text safely to numbers
  3. Convert million euros to full values
  4. Feed BW measure variables
  5. Refresh data source
  6. Apply dynamic dimension filters

SAC Script 

// Read and convert user inputs (Million EUR)

var bcMin = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(InputField_1.getValue());

var bcMax = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(InputField_2.getValue());

var devMin = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(InputField_3.getValue());

var devMax = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(InputField_4.getValue());

 

// Feed BW measure variables (convert to full value)

Table_Main.getDataSource().setVariableValue("VAR_BC_MIN", bcMin * 1000000);

Table_Main.getDataSource().setVariableValue("VAR_BC_MAX", bcMax * 1000000);

Table_Main.getDataSource().setVariableValue("VAR_DEV_MIN", devMin * 1000000);

Table_Main.getDataSource().setVariableValue("VAR_DEV_MAX", devMax * 1000000);

 

// Refresh BW Live data

Table_Main.getDataSource().refreshData();

 

// Helper table based dynamic filtering

var dsSource = Table_Helper.getDataSource();

var dsTarget = Table_Main.getDataSource();

 

var rs = dsSource.getResultSet();

var dimList = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

 

for (var i = 0; i < rs.length; i++) {

    var dim = rs[i]["DIM_PROJECT"];

    var measure = rs[i]["@MeasureDimension"];

 

    if (measure && measure.formattedValue !== "0" && measure.formattedValue !== "") {

        dimList.push(dim.id);

    }

}

 

if (dimList.length > 0) {

    dsTarget.setDimensionFilter("DIM_PROJECT", dimList);

} else {

    dsTarget.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_PROJECT");

}

Why This Approach Works

Technical Benefits:

- Fully BW Live compliant

- No implicit type conversion

- Stable scripting

 

Business Benefits:

- Simple user input

- Faster analysis

- Cleaner visuals

This approach fits daily bid and cost discussions.

Conclusion

Text Input driven measure variables provide high control with low complexity.

entry.title: Cleaning Zero and Blank Base Cost Records in SAP Analytics Cloud BW Live for Clear Variance Trends
entry.content:
Business Background

In BW Live–based cost analysis, variance trends are often affected by records that contain zero or blank Base Cost values.
These records usually belong to:

  • Old projects
  • Pass-through orders
  • Closure or migrated projects

Including them in trend analysis makes charts noisy and less meaningful for management discussions.

 

What the Execute Button Does

When the user clicks the Execute button:

  • WBS TOPs with zero or blank Base Cost values are removed
  • The remaining records are used to calculate:
    • Approximate cumulative variance
    • Year-wise variance trend
  • The chart becomes easier to read and interpret

At the same time, the story still provides:

  • One table and chart with all records
  • One table and chart without zero or blank records

This gives full transparency to the user.

 

Important Business Clarification

Removing these WBS TOPs does not impact the actual variance calculation in a material way.

Reason:

  • Zero or blank Base Cost values appear mainly in Main projects
  • These projects are mostly old or pass-through in nature
  • Proper Base Cost and Actuals are correctly tracked in Sub- projects

So the filtered view improves visual clarity, not financial accuracy.

 

Design Approach in SAP Analytics Cloud

The solution uses a helper table–based dynamic filtering pattern.

High-level logic:

  1. Read data from a helper table
  2. Identify WBS TOPs with non-zero Base Cost
  3. Collect only valid WBS TOP IDs
  4. Apply the filter dynamically to:
    • Main chart
    • Main table
  5. Remove the filter automatically if no valid records exist

This logic runs only when the user clicks Execute, keeping the story fast.

 

Simplified SAC Script

// Source helper table

var dsSource = Table_Helper.getDataSource();

 

// Target chart and table

var dsTargetChart = Chart_Main.getDataSource();

var dsTargetTable = Table_Main.getDataSource();

 

// Read result set

var rs = dsSource.getResultSet();

var validWbsList = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

 

// Collect WBS TOPs with non-zero and non-blank Base Cost

for (var i = 0; i < rs.length; i++) {

    var wbs = rs[i]["DIM_WBS_TOP"];

    var measure = rs[i]["@MeasureDimension"];

 

    if (measure && measure.formattedValue !== "0" && measure.formattedValue !== "") {

        validWbsList.push(wbs.id);

    }

}

 

// Apply or remove filters

if (validWbsList.length > 0) {

    dsTargetChart.setDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP", validWbsList);

    dsTargetTable.setDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP", validWbsList);

} else {

    dsTargetChart.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP");

    dsTargetTable.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP");

}

 

Why This Pattern Works Well

Technical Benefits

  • Fully compatible with BW Live
  • No hard-coded filters
  • Clean and reusable scripting
  • No impact on backend data

Business Benefits

  • Clear variance trends
  • Better year-wise comparison
  • Transparent view for auditors and controllers
  • Faster management discussions

 

Conclusion

Using an Execute button to remove WBS TOPs with zero or blank Base Cost values is a simple yet powerful way to improve variance trend analysis in SAP Analytics Cloud. By combining helper tables and dynamic dimension filtering, you get better insights without compromising data integrity.

entry.title: Troubleshooting SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Access Errors for BW Live Data in Microsoft Edge
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) provides powerful real-time analytics through BW Live connections. However, users frequently face access issues when opening BW Live stories in Microsoft Edge.

In most cases, these problems are not caused by BW or SAC models, but by:

  • Browser security restrictions in Microsoft Edge
  • Missing SAC or BW roles
  • Incomplete user profile or license assignment

This guide focuses only on BW Live access issues in Microsoft Edge and how to resolve them.

 

  1. Common SAC Access Errors for BW Live Users
  2. Missing User Profile or Role (BW Live Context)

Typical message:
“Please contact your administrator to assign the required role.”

What it means:

  • Your SAC user profile is not created, or
  • Your SAC license is missing, or
  • Required BW Live–related roles are not assigned

Without these, BW Live stories will not open, even if import models work.

Action:

  • Confirm SAC license assignment
  • Confirm BW Live access role with your administrator

 

  1. Browser Authorization Prompt in Microsoft Edge

What you see:

  • Microsoft Edge asks for username and password when opening a BW Live story

What it means:

  • User profile creation has started
  • SAC license is not yet fully assigned

This issue is more visible in BW Live stories, because they require live authentication.

Action:

  • Wait for license completion
  • Check request status with the administrator

 

  1. Unauthorized Error Due to IDM Lock (BW Live)

Typical error:

  • “Unauthorized”
  • SAML2 authentication error

What it means:

  • Your SAP user ID is locked in Identity Management (IDM)
  • BW Live authentication fails immediately

Action:

  • Contact administrator
  • Request IDM unlock

 

  1. BW Live Connection Fails in Microsoft Edge

Typical symptoms:

  • BW Live story opens but data does not load
  • “Unable to connect to BW system”
  • Blank tables or charts

Most common root cause in Edge:

  • Third-party cookies are blocked

This issue affects BW Live only, not import models.

 

  1. Microsoft Edge Settings Required for BW Live

Third-Party Cookies (Critical for BW Live)

Microsoft Edge may automatically disable third-party cookies every 90 days.

When this happens:

  • BW Live authentication fails
  • SAC stories stop working suddenly

 

How to Enable Third-Party Cookies in Edge

  1. Open a BW Live SAC story in Microsoft Edge
  2. Look for the eye symbol in the browser address bar
  3. Click the eye symbol
  4. Enable third-party cookies for the SAC site
  5. Refresh the page

In most cases, BW Live data loads immediately.

 

  1. Pop-Ups and Redirects (BW Live Requirement)

BW Live uses pop-ups for:

  • Authentication
  • Variable prompts

If pop-ups are blocked, BW Live cannot complete login.

Edge Configuration

  1. Go to Edge Settings
  2. Open Cookies and Site Permissions
  3. Select Pop-ups and redirects
  4. Add your SAC tenant URL to Allow

Reload the BW Live story after this change.

  1. Role-Based Access for BW Live Data

If SAC opens but BW Live data fails:

Possible reason:

  • Missing BW Live–specific role or view authorization

Action:

  • Ask administrator to raise a GRC request
  • Ensure both:
    • SAC role
    • BW Live / BW authorization role
      are included

 

Checking GRC Request Status

  1. Open GRC Home
  2. Navigate to Search Requests
  3. Track approval and completion

Do not rely only on email updates.

 

  1. Confirmation That BW Live Access Is Ready

You will receive an email from the SAP Authorization Batch system when:

  • SAC license is assigned
  • User profile is created
  • BW Live roles are active

After this, BW Live stories should open correctly in Microsoft Edge.

 

Final Tips for BW Live Users on Microsoft Edge

  • This guide applies only to BW Live data
  • Import models are usually not affected
  • Microsoft Edge needs periodic cookie checks
  • Pop-ups must be allowed
  • Both SAC and BW roles are mandatory

Checking browser settings first can save hours of troubleshooting.

 

Conclusion

Most SAC access errors for BW Live users in Microsoft Edge are caused by browser security settings or missing roles, not by BW or SAC issues. With the right Edge configuration and proper role assignment, BW Live stories work reliably and smoothly.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Scripting – My Practical Learnings (Part 1 of 2)
entry.content:
Introduction

While working with BW Live stories in SAP Analytics Cloud Advanced Mode, I learned that scripting must be defensive, explicit, and user-driven.
In this blog, I share the first three scripting learnings that consistently worked in real projects.

All examples below are error-free and production-safe.

 

  1. Always Convert Text Input Values Explicitly

Learning

Text Input widgets always return strings.
Using them directly in calculations or BW variables leads to errors.

Explicit conversion is mandatory.

 

Working Script Example

// Read value from Text Input

var inputValue = InputField_1.getValue();

 

// Convert string to number safely

var numericValue = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(inputValue);

Why this works

  • No implicit type conversion
  • No runtime errors
  • Fully supported in SAC

 

  1. Keep User Input Simple, Convert Units in Script

Learning

Business users prefer entering simple numbers, such as millions.
BW Live variables expect full numeric values.

The script must handle the conversion.

 

Working Script Example

// Convert million value to full amount and feed BW variable

Table_Main.getDataSource()

    .setVariableValue("VAR_COST_MIN", numericValue * 1000000);

Benefits

  • Clean user experience
  • Accurate BW filtering
  • No confusion for business users

 

  1. Refresh BW Live Data Only After Setting Variables

Learning

BW Live does not automatically refresh after variable updates.
Refreshing too early or multiple times causes inconsistent behavior.

Always refresh once, after all variables are set.

 

Working Script Example

// Refresh BW Live data after variable assignment

Table_Main.getDataSource().refreshData();

Best Practice

  • One refresh per Execute button
  • Never refresh inside loops

 

Conclusion – Part 1

These three learnings form the foundation of stable BW Live scripting:

  • Explicit conversion
  • User-friendly units
  • Controlled refresh

In Part 2, I will cover advanced but safe patterns for helper tables and dynamic filtering.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Scripting – My Practical Learnings (Part 2 of 2)
entry.content:
Introduction

After mastering input handling and refresh control, the next challenge in BW Live is dynamic filtering based on measure values.

Direct measure filtering is limited, so I learned to use helper tables with result set logic. The patterns below are stable and production-safe.

 

  1. Use Helper Tables to Filter Based on Measure Values

Learning

SAC does not allow direct measure-based filters easily.
A helper table can read result sets and drive intelligent filtering.

 

Working Script Example

// Get helper table data source

var dsSource = Table_Helper.getDataSource();

 

// Read result set

var rs = dsSource.getResultSet();

This works reliably after data is loaded.

 

  1. Always Handle Zero and Blank Measure Values Safely

Learning

Zero or blank values distort charts and trends.
They must be filtered carefully without breaking the story.

 

Working Script Example

// Create array for valid dimension members

var dimList = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

 

for (var i = 0; i < rs.length; i++) {

 

    var dimObj = rs[i]["DIM_KEY"];

    var measObj = rs[i]["@MeasureDimension"];

 

    if (measObj !== null &&

        measObj.formattedValue !== "0" &&

        measObj.formattedValue !== "") {

 

        dimList.push(dimObj.id);

    }

}

Why this is safe

  • No undefined access
  • Handles blank and zero values
  • Works for BW Live

 

  1. Always Handle the “No Valid Data” Scenario

Learning

If no valid records exist, filters must be removed.
Otherwise, users see empty or broken visuals.

 

Working Script Example

var dsTarget = Table_Main.getDataSource();

 

if (dimList.length > 0) {

    dsTarget.setDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY", dimList);

} else {

    dsTarget.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY");

}

This guarantees:

  • No stuck filters
  • Predictable behavior

 

Conclusion – Part 2

My key takeaway from SAC scripting is simple:

Stable scripts matter more than clever scripts.

By using helper tables, explicit checks, and safe filtering logic, BW Live stories remain fast, reliable, and easy to maintain.

entry.title: Datasphere (DSP) and SAC data and metadata versioning / backup and restore
entry.content:
Background:

Contrary to BW f.e. where full Versioning of all objects is available. Data backup directly of requests on the file-system/logical path (not SARA, but also SARA can be used). DSP and SAC have no such out-of-the-box solutions (except a handful of DSP objects). 

SAC: offers no Versioning nor Data protection 

DSP: Versioning exists for: Tables (including Remote), Views, Models, Task Chains, DACs, Replication Flows, Transformation Flows. Restore is possible only for: Tables (local only, not remote), Views, and Models. What is not versioned at all: Data Flows.

 

What exists is: Full DB backups (DB-Snapshots with RedoLogs) - Platform Backup: 

SAP: 

  • DSP and SAC Tenants: SAP creates a daily backup with 15-minute intervals for RedoLogs, but this is for disaster recovery and is not available to customers. These backups are retained for 14 days.
  • SAP HANA Cloud offers Back/Restore of the entire DB (daily plus 15-minutes RedoLogs) for 1-215 days.

3rd party (DB-snapshots):

  • Data Lakehouse (Databricks) - Connect Databricks and integrate the data into the Amazon S3 layer. Use Amazon BackUp feature, but full DB. 
  • Google's Data Cloud - Same as Databricks, but data will be in stored on Google servers instead of Amazon S3.

 

Solution/steps:

SAP Suggests pushing the data to a separate tenant - requires more admin overhead and added costs for the 'backup' tenant or creating content packages with data. 

 

Alternatives for Data backup:

#1 Push data via Replication Flow into a separated DB (create a connection to own DB / costs compared to S3, Google, separated DSP tenant are negligible). Replication Flow can export data (this is the PI/EAI/EDI functionality of DSP), Replication flows may require additional costs, but backups can be run during off-peak hours.

#2 Pull data via OData to separate DB (f.e. Azure Data Factory - create Linked Service, Create Connection, where you specify the DSP Space.View/Table, create Dataset and 'SINK' the data - suggestion is to drop and recreate the table to avoid errors when the DSP view/table structure changes)

#3 Store data in local tables - These tables would be in a separate space. Tables need to be set to disk (not in-memory), as you do not want the memory footprint to be expanded unnecessary. Least efficient alternative. 

SAC Planning data can be pushed to DSP via CDI connection (if Native is used) and then backed-up. In case of Seamless planning, the data is already in DSP stored. SAC Actuals data are expected to be acquired from DSP in our case. 

 

Alternatives for Metadata backup:

DSP and SAC via transport files -> Via CLI an automated script can be created (as of now there is no automated export job available). 

DSP offers versioning for: Tables (including Remote), Views, Models, Task Chains, DACs, Replication Flows, Transformation Flows. What is not versioned at all: Data Flows. 

 

Restore: 

SAC -> transport files. Just re-deploy into your DEV tenant and thus 'restore' the f.e. Story in the version you need. Helps a lot as complex stories with complex Java-Scripting tent to get corrupt - f.e. lose the model information. 

DSP -> Restore is possible only for: Tables (local only, not remote), Views, and Models. Everything else is only transport files. 

're-transport' is also possible from TST or PROD tenants back to DEV tenant of course.

 

References

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/0c3780ad05fd417fa27b98418535debd/ae2b2b7117c84b0aab670ddd2f...

https://help.sap.com/docs/hana-cloud/sap-hana-cloud-administration-guide/backup-and-recovery

https://me.sap.com/notes/3491324

https://me.sap.com/notes/3574161

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/43509d67b8b84e66a30851e832f66911/586699519c83489bb778878236...

 

Main blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/bw-vs-datasphere-dsp-amp-sac/ba-p/1428...

entry.title: No nightmare before Christmas - our SAC carol 🎄
entry.content:
Santa’s Journey

"Holly, jolly Christmas! Yeah, right... more like gloomy doomy, based on the numbers. Who can keep up with that?" - another year Santa is desperately studying all the certain and uncertain details of his ambitious Christmas Eve tour.
Simply having a manual process (… far from wonderful) makes it difficult to adapt to sudden snowstorms, last-minute gift list changes, reindeer fatigue, and even unexpected chimney blockages. Last Christmas, Santa gave all his “heart” work and almost gave it away. This year, to save him from tears, he’d give it to someone special.
Having a word with himself: “You better watch out, you better not cry. You will find a solution.”
He’s browsing the Internet when he suddenly hears the herald angels sing: SAP – Santa Application Products. He calls immediately …
What can we say, who corrects Santa, right? Especially, since we have the perfect solution for Analytics and Planning: SAP Analytics Cloud 

So, Santa called - seeking for help, to plan his ambitious Christmas Eve tour. Naturally, we pulled up the sleeves, getting to work and started with the natural step #1: our data model:

Thanks to our harmonized model and the seamless planning integration, the model can be easily created and directly integrated with SAP Datasphere.

Santa’s planning sheet has already provided a few details and seems to outline a driver-based model. We will need to factor in households, the miles those reindeer have to cover, and of course some time for the actual gift drop – and plus a little extra for those delicious cookies of yours 🍪🧋.

Other influencing factors? Well, there is the “Weather Delay Factor” or the “Reindeer Fatigue Rate” because even Rudolph needs a break. And of course, the “Magic Time Compression Factor” – we need to be real here, how else could Santa deliver that many packages in just one night. 🕰️

This leaves us with the following model structure (shown here as an account dimension but measure calculations would work equally):

Calculations allow us to report, simulate and optimize a wide range of metrics and key KPIs, such as the overall “On Time Indicator”! Inverse formulas allow top-down planning, so Santa can set those ambitious goals (like optimizing the time needed before “magic”):

With the flexible hierarchy management tool, we can easily separate drivers and KPIs and thanks to multi-language support, Santa´s helpers can work in their native tongue.

Once the model is set up, we continue with step 2: the data. Thankfully, Santa has provided all his handwritten plans from previous years, so we can use the integrated Business User File Upload to populate our model – based on the sheet Santa provided!

Now, with all the data transferred into the model, Santa can get to work: All the magic built-into the model is already functioning - calculations are performed and the “On time indicator” (KPI Threshold) highlights areas that need his attention. With an ad hoc generated Value Driver Tree, Santa gets a clear overview over his model structure, all drivers and KPIs, even input-enabled options for simulations right at the model level. And the drill-down feature allows breakdowns of certain drivers into the various dimensions (e.g. Region).

Also, a dedicated report allows Santa to quickly navigate through the different regions:

Oh, oh! In Europe the “On Time Indicator” is off – time for a new scenario sheet, allowing Santa to adjust those drivers and optimize, so we can be on time for Europe as well!

A Client Calculation “Delta” helps to identify the adjustments made, and a new version ”Scenario A” allows various simulation scenarios without changing the data in public data sets. This way, only proven adjustments are submitted to the final plan and made available to everyone. The weather forecast for Europe indicates a cold but calm and clear night, so the “Weather Delay Factor” can be adjusted! It´s also a good time to test that new Reindeer Power Granulate, bringing the “Fatigue Rate” down – our Reindeers will have more energy! With just a few slight adjustments the “On Time Indicator” is back to where it should be! Plan confirmed and submitted – with extra care for certain regions bringing Santa back on track!

As we still have a few uncertainties, Santa needs to gain more confidence: How ambitious is the plan, or in other words, how likely will he reach his goal (or is it our goal 😉)? Luckily, right from the simulation table, by selecting the key KPI (“Total Time Required”), he can run a Monte Carlo Simulation using SAC Compass. After adjusting the drivers (which uncertainties do we want to simulate?) and setting the right corridor, e.g. we have a hard limit at 24hours, Compass will present us with the result:

Wohoo! After running tens of thousands of simulations across all the magical drivers, the results are in: Santa has a 68% chance of hitting his target! Thanks to the tight integration of simulation and planning, we can say with a certain level of confidence … 🥁 : Christmas is saved for another year! The sleigh is ready, the reindeer are fueled up, and the data magic worked its wonders.

Now behind the scenes, the elves are already preparing the 2nd version using built-in capabilities, including:

  • Datasphere Integration / Live Versions – to leverage various data sources and the tight integration via seamless planning
  • Asymmetric Reporting – comparing budget, plan and forecasts
  • MyMetrics – to really manage that important KPIs
  • Predictive Forecasting – project potential forecasts and uncertainties, pre-fill plans allowing faster simulation and insights
  • An Excel-Frontend, allowing convenience features in Microsoft Excel paired with the power of an integrated, in-cloud planning solution

but we will leave that for another episode (and evolution of our planning application)! 😉

 

Merry Christmas everyone! 🎅🎄

entry.title: SAC Story Bookmark. Unable to save a bookmark.
entry.content:
Issue with bookmarks. Unable to save bookmark error message. 
In log (Developer Tools) a message appears: We can’t have another bookmark with the name … in this target resource. 

There are no bookmarks in the story self however. 

Reason was in the Bookmarks version which was changed, what caused all old bookmarks to be invalidated, but not deleted. Means the bookmarks are still in the background, but not visible for the user in the Story self.

Go to Story \ Bookmarks, choose Invalid bookmarks and delete.

entry.title: Using ChatGPT Personalization Settings for Effective SAP Analytics Cloud Scripting
entry.content:
Introduction
SAP Analytics Cloud scripting, especially with BW Live data, is sensitive to small mistakes.
Implicit type conversion, reused variables, or unclear logic can easily cause runtime errors or unexpected results.
To avoid this, I configured ChatGPT personalization settings specifically for SAC scripting.
These settings guide ChatGPT to generate safe, predictable, and production-ready scripts instead of generic JavaScript-like code.
This blog explains the key personalization rules and how they help in daily SAC development.

1. Enforcing Explicit Data Type Conversion
Why This Matters
Text Input widgets in SAC always return strings.
Using them directly in calculations or variable feeding is unsafe.
By instructing ChatGPT to never use auto type conversion, the generated scripts become stable.

Personalization Rule
• Always use ConvertUtils for string, number, and date conversion
• Never rely on implicit conversion

Resulting Script Pattern
var inputVal = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(InputField_1.getValue());
This avoids:
• Runtime errors
• BW variable failures
• Unexpected results

2. Treating Every Event as Independent
Why This Matters
In SAC, scripts run in event-based isolation.
Global variables or reused variables can break execution order.
By forcing ChatGPT to treat each event independently, scripts remain predictable.

Personalization Rule
• Declare all variables explicitly in each event
• Do not reuse variables implicitly
• Do not use global variables

Resulting Script Pattern
var dsTarget = Table_Main.getDataSource();
Each script becomes:
• Self-contained
• Easy to debug
• Safe during future changes

3. Forcing Simple and Minimal Logic
Why This Matters
Complex loops and nested conditions reduce readability and increase risk in BW Live stories.
By instructing ChatGPT to always start with simple and minimal working scripts, the output remains practical.

Personalization Rule
• Always provide simple, minimal, and working scripts first
• Avoid unnecessary loops and complex logic

Resulting Benefit
• Scripts are easier to review
• Performance is more predictable
• Business users face fewer issues

4. Enforcing Correct SAC API Usage
Why This Matters
Generic JavaScript examples often misuse SAC APIs.
Incorrect use of DataSource APIs causes silent failures.
Personalization ensures that ChatGPT:
• Uses DataSource API correctly
• Applies feed binding and dimension filtering properly

Resulting Script Pattern
dsTarget.setDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY", dimList);
Instead of unsupported or incorrect logic.

5. Strict Commenting and Readability Rules
Why This Matters
SAC scripts are often maintained by multiple people.
Clear comments reduce dependency on the original developer.

Personalization Rule
• Use /* */ for multiline comments
• Use // for single-line comments

Resulting Script Pattern
/* Apply dimension filter safely */
dsTarget.setDimensionFilter("DIM_KEY", dimList);
This improves:
• Maintainability
• Knowledge transfer
• Long-term support

6. Aligning Output with BW Live Reality
Why This Matters
BW Live behaves differently from import models.
Scripts must respect:
• Live refresh behavior
• Variable dependency
• Performance constraints
Personalization settings guide ChatGPT to generate scripts that:
• Refresh data explicitly
• Avoid unsupported shortcuts
• Respect BW Live limitations

Conclusion
ChatGPT can be a powerful assistant for SAP Analytics Cloud scripting, but only when it is guided correctly.
By defining clear personalization settings focused on explicit typing, isolation, simplicity, and correct API usage, the generated scripts become reliable and production-ready.
For BW Live scripting, these settings are not optional. They are essential.

entry.title: Building a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views – Part 1: ID & Description
entry.content:
Table of Contents:

  • Overview on this Blog
  • Prerequisites for this blog
  • Problem Statement
  • Modeling Approach
  • Technical Details and Source code
  • Conclusion

Overview on this Blog

Hi SAP Community,
This is part one of a three part blog series on How to Build a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views.

  • Part1 - Loading the ID & DESC of the GL
  • Part2 - Loading the hierarchy
  • Part3 - Loading the Desc for the Hierarchy nodes 

Prerequisites for this blog

  • Basic understanding of SAC, SAC Planning & Public Dimensions.
  • CDS Views, ODATA, creating a service.
  • FSV, GL Account Hierarchy.

Problem Statement

Let's understand our objective first before we begin with the technical details. We will be building the CDS view required for populating the GL account (Public dimension) in SAC Planning. Our end goal  is to build a fully functioning future-proof GL hierarchy for our Public dimension in SAC.

GL Account Hierarchy in SAC

Modeling Approach

With any SAC Planning implementation project, Our end goal would be to create input sheets for planning users to input their budget data, ultimately retracting the data to S4/HANA ACDOCP.

In order for the input sheets to be meaningful, we need to have relevant dimensions in place for building the model. In most cases, these planning are to be done at a GL account Level. These GL's are maintained in a Financial Statement version (FSV) in the S4/HANA System. It can be previewed using the transaction code OB58. 

Now that we know we need to fetch these GL accounts, 'Why don't we import all the GL's into one public dimension and build its hierarchy?' , Short answer would be, it will be messy and having too much unwanted information. In SAC Planning, this directly impacts input form usability and planning accuracy.

The best approach would be to tackle planning in modules, i.e., SALES, OPEX, WORKFORCE, CAPEX, INVENTORY rather than one big FINANCE planning. So inorder to handle these individual modules we need to have independent GL account public dimensions for these processes. Eg.(Z_SALES_GLACCOUNT, Z_OPEX_GLACCOUNT,.. etc).

Next question, 'There must be a way to selectively filter out only the GL's needed for my process. How do we restrict only a portion of the FSV dynamically?' 

The condition is, it should work seamlessly irrespective of any new GLs added into the system. Hardcoding GL accounts & their hierarchy will definitely fail when a new GL gets added or when the GL gets restructured into a different node. 

FSV

 

The master node of the FSV is not likely to change. Hence we will create a mechanism that lets us capture the GLs underneath one of the master nodes. These structures are called FSV Item key. Each branch of the FSV has its own FSV Item key and it can traverse to a maximum depth of Level 8. Let's uncover one thing at time. So if we need to build a GL Account dimension for storing the master data of all the GLs related to Sales and its hierarchy, we just need to consider the GLs under nodes Turnover(08), CostofSales(09), OtherIncome(11) and Taxation(17). On Doing so, all the nodes under these and the respective GLs would be captured. This approach ensures that newly added GLs automatically flow into SAC without any redesign

 

Technical Details and Source code

This is a 3 part blog, I'll summarize the content as below:

  • Part1 - Loading the ID & DESC of the GL
  • Part2 - Loading the hierarchy (Leaf & Headers)
  • Part3 - Loading the Desc for the Hierarchy nodes 

Query Details

In this Part1 blog, we will create Query1 [1 ID and Desc Mapping], to populate the ID and Description of every SALES related GL from our FSV.

Step 1:
First we need to obtain all the GL IDs and Desc present within the system.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_GL_M'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'For getting GL Master'
define view ZCDS_GL_MASTER as select distinct from 
ska1 as a inner join skat as b
    on a.saknr = b.saknr
{
    a.saknr, --GL
    b.txt20, --Short Text desc
    b.txt50  --Long Text desc
}
where a.ktopl = 'CGC1' and b.spras='E' and b.ktopl='CGC1'

Step 2:

Secondly, we need to restrict the GLs belonging to our FSV (FSV1). Joining ZCDS_GL_MASTER with HRRP_NODE will enable us to apply filter on HRYID field (For selecting our targeted FSV).

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_GLM'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'For Mapping the GL account master'
@Analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@OData.publish: true
define view ZCDS_GLACCOUNT_ID_DESC                    
as select from 
ZCDS_GL_MASTER as a inner join hrrp_node as b
on a.saknr = b.nodevalue
{
    key a.saknr,  --GL Account
    key b.hryid,  --Hierarchy ID
    key b.parnode, --Parent
    a.txt20,      --Short text desc
    a.txt50,      --Long text desc
    b.nodetype.   --Node Type
}

where (b.nodetype='D' or b.nodetype='L') and (b.hryid='FSV1')

Now that we have the ZCDS_GLACCOUNT_ID_DESC CDS view ready, We need to expose it via ODATA, create a service and then consume it in our SAC Public dimension.

Once the OData has been exposed and the respective Service has been created, We can now go to our SAC Public Dimension which we have created and choose S4/HANA connection and type in our CDS view query to fetch the data.

Create the First query with the below selected fields and the FSV item keys suitable for your Business process for Loading the ID and Description.

Be sure to map GL to ID and GL Account long text to Description

The sample result would be like this. 

ID

Description

Hierarchy

Account type

40010000

Revenue - Good (Export)

 

 

40010001

Revenue - Good (Service)

 

 

 

Conclusion

In this first part of the series, we focused on loading the GL Account ID and Description required for SAC Planning by selectively filtering GLs from the Financial Statement Version using CDS views. This step ensures that only relevant GL accounts are brought into the SAC public dimension, keeping the model clean and usable for planning.

In Part 2, we will build on this foundation and cover how to load the GL hierarchy structure, including both leaf and header nodes, using CDS views. This will help complete the hierarchy needed for drill-up and planning input in SAC.

If you have any doubts along the way, feel free to reach out to me in the comments below and Don't forget to Follow my profile if you find this BlogPost helpful. 👍

entry.title: Extending an SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget in SAP Analytics Cloud to Deliver Top-N Hierarchical In
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) does not provide a native, built-in Sankey chart as part of its standard visualization catalog. As a result, Sankey-style visualizations in SAC are typically implemented using custom widgets.

In mid-2024, while working on an enterprise analytics engagement, I encountered a requirement to visualize:

  • Top N parent entities (for example, service providers)
  • And, for each parent, the Top M child entities independently ranked per parent (for example, services offered)

All of this needed to be displayed within a single Sankey visualization, enabling users to immediately understand concentration and distribution patterns without navigating multiple charts.

To address this requirement, I explored SAC’s Custom Widget framework and extended an existing SAP-provided sample Sankey custom widget into a production-ready solution.

I have intentionally included the development and deployment steps in detail so that consultants or developers who are completely new to Sankey custom widgets in SAP Analytics Cloud can deploy and validate the solution end-to-end by following this blog.

SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget as the Starting Point

Since SAP Analytics Cloud does not include a native Sankey chart, I referred to a sample Sankey custom widget implementation shared by SAP through the SAP Community. This SAP-provided sample demonstrates how a Sankey diagram can be rendered using the SAC Custom Widget framework and served as a technical starting point for my work.

The SAP sample was very helpful as a technical reference, as it illustrated:

  • Custom widget structure and lifecycle
  • Binding SAC model data to a widget
  • Rendering a Sankey diagram using JavaScript

During mid-2024, while actively working on this requirement, I engaged in the comments section of that SAP Community blog (SAP Analytics Cloud: Custom Widget & Widget Add-Ons Samples Preview) under my SAP Community user@GovindaRaoBanothu45 , discussing feasibility and implementation boundaries.

While the sample clarified the basic rendering approach, it also highlighted functional gaps when applied to enterprise-scale analytical requirements.

Why the SAP Sample Sankey Widget Was Not Sufficient

The SAP-provided Sankey custom widget was intentionally designed as a generic sample. Its behavior was to render all nodes and all links returned by the bound dataset.

However, the sample widget did not support the enterprise analytical requirement I was addressing, specifically:

  • No Top-N filtering at the parent level
  • No independent ranking of child nodes per parent
  • No data trimming prior to Sankey rendering
  • Limited usability for large, real-world datasets

As a result, while the SAP sample demonstrated how to render a Sankey chart, it did not meet the analytical or usability needs of an enterprise dashboard.

This gap required extending and enhancing the SAP sample Sankey custom widget with additional, original logic to reshape the dataset before rendering.

High-Level Architecture of the Extended Sankey Widget

The Sankey rendering mechanism remains aligned with the SAP sample, while the data-transformation layer represents the core extension.

Development Environment and Prerequisites

Prerequisites

To get started, ensure that you have:

  • Access to SAP Analytics Cloud with Optimized Design Experience enabled
  • Node.js installed on your local machine
  • Visual Studio Code (VS Code) installed
  • Basic understanding of JavaScript and JSON

Development Environment Setup

Install Node.js

  1. Download Node.js from: https://nodejs.org
  2. Verify installation:
node -v
npm -v

Install Visual Studio Code

  1. Download VS Code from: https://code.visualstudio.com
  2. Use VS Code as the primary editor for developing and maintaining the custom widget files.

Set Up the Project Folder

  1. Create a project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode).
  2. Open the folder in Visual Studio Code.
  3. Create the following files:
  • main.js – core widget logic and Sankey rendering
  • index.json – metadata and resource configuration
  • hash256.js – Node.js script for integrity key generation

Sankey Custom Widget – Standard Project Structure

For the standard Sankey implementation, I created a dedicated project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode or any relevant project name). This folder contains all the supporting and required files needed to build and deploy the Sankey custom widget in SAP Analytics Cloud.

The project folder includes:

  • main.js
    The web component JavaScript file that contains the core widget logic and Sankey rendering code (mandatory).
  • index.json
    The metadata file that defines the custom widget, its properties, and resource references (mandatory).
  • sankeyChartStyling.js
    An optional styling component used to expose styling options in the widget’s styling panel (optional).
  • build/ folder
    Contains the helper script hash256.js, which is used to generate SHA-256 integrity keys for the JavaScript files.

Note: Styling files (Styling.js, sankeyChartStyling.js, or xxxxStyling.js) are optional and may not be required for all custom widgets.
However, the web component JavaScript file (main.js or equivalent) and the metadata file (index.json) are mandatory for every SAP Analytics Cloud custom widget. The build folder is included purely for maintainability and ease of understanding.
Technically, the hash256.js file can also be placed directly in the main project folder. Including it in a separate subfolder is optional and does not impact deployment, as long as the final ZIP file complies with SAP Analytics Cloud’s upload requirements.

Creating Integrity Keys and Deploying the Code

SAP Analytics Cloud supports SHA-256 integrity validation to ensure uploaded JavaScript resources are not modified.

Generating Integrity Keys

  1. Open a Node.js command prompt
  2. Navigate to the folder containing hash256.js
  3. Execute the script

Example output:

  • main.js: sha256-6134FFLCQYpH7x8gx29H1xJyRbitpf/guj5UGKhJ25Q=
  • sankeyChartStyling.js:  sha256-AR0uDO+9h8nu9EyJotSinZ2APDWD5Ja2JmdFcZCH1Xo=

Note: If additional JavaScript resource files are included, their corresponding sha256- integrity keys must also be added to the index.json file under the resources section.

Similarly, the file names must be updated in hash256.js before generating integrity keys for those files.

Core Enhancement: Top-N Parent and Top-M Child Logic

The following snippets are representative excerpts from the working implementation.
Full scripts are intentionally not published, as this widget was delivered as part of an enterprise engagement.

In the widget, the SAC data binding is first normalized into an array (data) containing parent node, child node, and measure value fields.

Step 1: Aggregate Measure by Parent

const parentTotals = {};
data.forEach(row => {
  parentTotals[row.parentNode] =
    (parentTotals[row.parentNode] || 0) + Number(row.measureValue);
});

Step 2: Rank and Retain Top-N Parents

const topParents = Object.entries(parentTotals)
  .sort((a, b) => b[1] - a[1])
  .slice(0, TOP_N_PARENT_NODES)
  .map(entry => entry[0]);

Step 3: Rank and Retain Top-M Children per Parent

const filteredLinks = [];
topParents.forEach(parent => {
  const children = data
    .filter(row => row.parentNode === parent)
    .sort((a, b) => b.measureValue - a.measureValue)
    .slice(0, TOP_N_CHILD_NODES);

  children.forEach(child => {
    filteredLinks.push({
      source: parent,
      target: child.childNode,
      value:  child.measureValue
    });
  });
});

Step 4: Rebuild Nodes

const nodes = [...new Set(
  filteredLinks.flatMap(l => [l.source, l.target])
)].map(name => ({ name }));

Step 5: Render Sankey

sankey.nodes(nodes).links(filteredLinks).layout(32);

The rendering follows the SAP sample approach; the innovation lies in the data-transformation logic.

Once all required files and script updates are ready, let’s deploy the custom widget into SAP Analytics Cloud.

Deploy the Custom Widget

  1. Create a ZIP File:
    • Include main.js, index.json, and optional styling files in a .zip file.
  2. Upload to SAP Analytics Cloud:
    • Navigate to the Custom Widgets section in SAC.
    • Upload the .json and .zip files.
  3. Test the Widget:
    • Add the custom widget to a story and configure data sources.

Select the JSON metadata file from your local system.

Next, select the resource file that is .zip file of main.js, index.json and styling.js or any other file related to this chart.

Now you can the widget in "Custom Widgets" section.

Observe the warning messages below with and/without integrity checks in the list of custom widgets

We have done custom widget deployment and will use the same in stories. Let's see how to access this in story 2.0.

 

From the builder panel, select your data model, set measure, set a hierarchical dimension and edit the default colors of the different depths from the Styling panel.

Below screenshot show the usage of the Styling.JS file.

In case the java script files get modified / tampered you get the below error while creating chart using custom widget in SAC story.

Validated Sankey Variants  - Let's validate 3 different scenarios

  • SAP sample Sankey (baseline):

                          

  • Top 1 parent + Top 5 child nodes:
    • This is the custom code and the main.js file is completely different than standard code with the key components are the below conditions below.

                        

                       Result of the above changes,

                    

  • Top 3 parents + Top 5 children:

                          

                        Result of the above changes,

                       

This incremental approach helped validate correctness before applying the logic to larger Top-N configurations.

Acknowledgment

I would like to thank @marouferchichi for actively engaging in the SAP Community blog comments and helping clarify the capabilities and boundaries of the sample Sankey custom widget.

The final implementation described here represents my independent extension and delivery of that sample to meet enterprise-level analytical requirements.

Conclusion

This blog demonstrates how a SAP sample Sankey custom widget can be extended into a production-grade Top-N hierarchical Sankey visualization using SAP Analytics Cloud’s Custom Widget framework.

For similar enterprise scenarios, this approach provides a reusable and scalable pattern.

entry.title: Building a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views - Part 2 ( Building the Hierarchy )
entry.content:
Table of Contents:

  • Overview on this Blog
  • Approach
  • Technical Details and Source code
  • Leaf and header node Handling in SAC
  • Query 2: Hierarchy for Leaf Level
  • Query 3: Hierarchy for Header Level
  • Conclusion

Overview on this Blog

Hi SAP Community,
This is part two of a three part blog series on How to Build a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views.

  • Part1 - Loading the ID & DESC of the GL
  • Part2 - Loading the hierarchy
  • Part3 - Loading the Desc for the Hierarchy nodes 

In Part 1, we focused on loading the GL Account ID and Description into an SAC public dimension by selectively filtering GLs from the Financial Statement Version (FSV). This ensured that only the GL accounts relevant for our planning process were loaded, avoiding unnecessary noise in SAC input forms. If you haven't read part1, I recommend you reading that first before this blog.

In this part, we will extend the same approach and focus on loading the GL hierarchy structure required for SAC Planning. This includes both leaf-level GL accounts and the header nodes that form the hierarchy.

 

Approach

Although SAP provides standard CDS hierarchy views(C_GLAccountHierarchyNode) , it is not feasible to consume a portion of the FSV with the available CDS View.

Instead of loading the entire GL hierarchy, we restrict ourselves to specific FSV branches relevant to the planning module (Sales, OPEX, CAPEX, etc.). The important assumption here is that the master nodes of the FSV do not change and the FSV is limited to a maximum of 8 Level of drill down , making them reliable anchors for hierarchy extraction.

The hierarchy is constructed by:

  1. Identifying the leaf-level GL accounts
  2. Traversing upwards level by level until the root node
  3. Capturing all intermediate hierarchy nodes in the process

This traversal is implemented using multiple CDS views, Since CDS does not support recursion we would be iteratively joining and passing the parent of lower levels as the Children of next level until we reach the root. At the final step, all hierarchy levels are unioned into a single CDS view, which is then exposed via OData and consumed in the SAC public dimension. 

Don't worry if it feels confusing at first, it will start to make lot more sense once we see the CDS architecture and Source code.

Technical Details and Source code

ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE

This is the Base hierarchy view that combines HRRP_NODE with the standard CDS view (C_GLAccountHierarchyNode) to fetch the required FSV nodes and underlying hierarchy nodes. The reason we have joined HRRP_NODE is to obtain the node details. This CDS view will be propagated to the top level and be used as a foundation by higher CDS views.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_HIER'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'GL hierarchy Foundation'
@Analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@OData.publish: true
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE as 


select distinct from hrrp_node as a
inner join C_GLAccountHierarchyNode as b
    on a.hryid = b.GLAccountHierarchy and a.nodevalue = b.GLAccount
  {
    key a.hryid,
    key a.hrynode,
    key a.parnode,
    key a.nodevalue,
    a.nodetype,
    b.GLAccount,
    b.HierarchyNode,
    b.ParentNode,
    b.NodeType as STD_nodetype
}
where (

(a.hryid='FSV1') and. -- Replace with your relevant FSV for SAC Planning
(a.nodetype='L' or a.nodetype='D') and  --Fetches line items containing Leaf or Directory nodes.

-- Filters only the relevant Nodes needed for Planning. 
-- ParNode value may differ based on your FSV.
((a.parnode='08' or a.parnode='09'or a.parnode='017' or a.parnode='011')                   //Sales         (08->Turnover, 09->COS, 017-> Taxation, 011->Other income)
or (a.parnode='013' or a.parnode='014' or a.parnode='016')              //OPEX          (013->Selling & distribution cost, 014->General & Admin cost, 016-> Finance cost)
or (a.parnode='012')                                                    //Workforce     (012->Indirect payroll cost)
or (a.parnode='00ASSETS' or a.parnode='00LIABILITS' or a.parnode='028')                //CAPEX         (00ASSETS->ASSETS, 00LIABILITS->LIABILITIES & EQUITY, 028->Depreciation)
or (a.parnode='0117'))                                                  //Inventory     (0117-> Inventory)
)

ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE:

This CDS View provides a clean GL-only child–parent mapping within the hierarchy, used as a reusable base for hierarchy traversal.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_GLBASE'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'For getting Plannable GLs'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as select distinct from C_GLAccountHierarchyNode as a

    {
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    a.GLAccount,
    a.HierarchyNode as Child,
    a.ParentNode as Parent,
    a.SACAccountType,
    a.NodeType as STD_nodetype
}
where (

(a.GLAccountHierarchy='FSV1') --Replace with your FSV
and (a.NodeType='N' or a.NodeType='R') 

)

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL8_LEAF:

Using ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE we will extract all the Leaf GLs and its immediate parent. Also while keeping track of the MasterParent.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL8'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Leaf level 8 - Most granular'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL8_LEAF as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE as a {
    a.parnode as MasterParent,
    a.nodevalue as Child,
    a.ParentNode as Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL7_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL7'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level7 - One step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL7_PARENT as select distinct from 

ZCDS_GLHIER_BACKBONE as a 
{
    a.hryid,
    a.nodetype,
    a.parnode as MasterParent,
    a.ParentNode
}
The Code below this portion is simple and easy to follow along, The concept is simple.
Pass the parent of one level to the child of the higher level, that will give the parent child relationship all the way till the root level is reached.
 
ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL6_PARENT:
@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL6'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level6 - Two step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL6_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL7_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.ParentNode
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL5_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL5'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level5 - Three step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL5_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL6_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL4_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL4'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level4 - Four step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL4_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL5_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}
ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL3_PARENT:
@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL3'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level3 - Five step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL3_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL4_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL2_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL2'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level2 - Six step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL2_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL3_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}

ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL1_PARENT:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL1'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Parent Level1 - 7 step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL1_PARENT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL2_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}
ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL0_ROOT:
After iterating the same procedure 8 times, we would have traversed 8 levels above the leaf which is also apparently the root node.
We have established 8 levels of iterations to achieve the maximum depth of 8levels of drill down, i.e, the maximum level of drill down possible in the S4/HANA FINANCE module for the creation of FSV.
@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_LVL0'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Root Level - 8 step above leaf'
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL0_ROOT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_GL_BASE as a inner join ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL1_PARENT as b on a.Child = b.Parent
{
    a.GLAccountHierarchy,
    b.MasterParent,
    a.Child,
    a.Parent
}
ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC:
At the final layer we would be unioning all the underlying levels ( Lvl0- root, lvl 1 to Lvl6 - Intermediate nodes, Lvl8 - Leaf).
The important thing here is to retain the MasterParent, which lets us identify which part of master branch the intermediate nodes and leaves are from.
 
If the source system has maintained the SACAccountType then well and good, if not you can maintain the SACAccountType like I did. (INC- income, EXP - expense, AST - Asset, LEQ - Liabilities, NFIN - NonFinancial). These will play crucial role in the aggregation, as GLs with AccountType EXP, LEQ will be subtracted rather than getting added. This will help SAC understand the signage and what to do next.
@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_TOP'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Union of all levels 1 to 8'
@Analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@OData.publish: true
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC as select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL8_LEAF as a 
{
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Children' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL6_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL5_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}

union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL4_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL3_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL2_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL1_PARENT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}
union 

select distinct from ZCDS_GLHIER_LVL0_ROOT as a {
    key a.MasterParent,
    key a.Parent,
    key a.Child,
    //a.SACAccountType,
    case when a.Parent='' then '' else(case when (a.MasterParent='08' or a.MasterParent='011') then 'INC' else (case when (a.MasterParent='00ASSETS' or a.MasterParent='0117') then 'AST' else (case when a.MasterParent='00LIABILITS' then 'LEQ' else 'EXP' end) end) end) end as SACAccountType,
    'Node' as Nodetype
}

Leaf and header node Handling in SAC

The hierarchy loading is split into two logical parts:

  • Nodetype - Children (Leaf nodes): All Leaf GLs and it's immediate parent
  • Nodetype - Node (Header nodes): All intermediate Nodes and their respective parents upto root.

We would be Loading the hierarchy in two steps in SAC as per the concept above. We will be using our ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC cds view.

Query 2: Hierarchy for Leaf Level

Remember the MasterParent field we kept Intact? With the help of that we can choose whichever MasterNode we want to load into our public dimension. If you are loading the Hierarchy for the SALES GL Account dimension, just simply select the MasterNodes that point to Sales. In our Part1 blog, we loaded the GLs of nodes Turnover(08), CostofSales(09), OtherIncome(11) and Taxation(17), So we'll do the same over here. 


In this query2, we will be loading only the leaf and its immediate hierarchy first. Hence we have selected Nodetype as 'Children'. The below image will give you a clear picture on what is happening.

Since queries in public dimensions work on update method, the hierarchy & Account type property will get updated based on the above mapped information.

The sample result would be like this. 

ID

Description

Hierarchy

Account type

40010000

Revenue - Good (Export)

FSV1_019

INC

40010001

Revenue - Good (Service)

FSV1_019

INC

Query 3: Hierarchy for Header Level

Now that the Hierarchy for the leaf level is done, the remaining thing to concentrate now is to populate the nodes and its respective hierarchy details. The only difference being we just need to create another query with the same dimensions, but the important thing is to change the filter for Nodetype as 'Node'.

This will fetch only the details from our intermediate levels. From Lvl6 to Root level.

In this query3, we will be loading only the nodes and its hierarchy, this continues all the way till the root. Hence we have selected Nodetype as 'Node'. The below image will give you a complete picture on what is happening.

The sample result would be like this.

Conclusion

In this blog, we covered how to build a GL hierarchy for SAC Planning by selectively extracting FSV branches and traversing the hierarchy using multiple CDS views. This layered approach ensures a clean and future proof hierarchy in SAC. In the next part, we will focus on loading descriptions for hierarchy header nodes to complete the setup.

I hope this blog was helpful. This was my first time explaining something in detail. If you liked this level of explanation, do let me know. I’ll consider this feedback while writing my upcoming blogs. ✌️

entry.title: Authorization setup for SAC Import Model from S4 ABAP CDS Views
entry.content:
Purpose of this document

The purpose of this blog is to explain how to implement data-level authorization in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories when:

  • Data is extracted from SAP S/4HANA CDS Views
  • The connection type is Import Model
  • Authorization must be enforced based on Company Code and Plant

This approach ensures that users can access only the data they are authorized to see, even though the data is physically stored in SAC.

 

Business Use Case

In many finance and controlling scenarios:

  • A single SAC Story is shared across multiple business users
  • Users belong to different Company Codes and Plant
  • Data is periodically imported from SAP S/4HANA into SAC

Since Import Models store data in SAC, runtime authorisation from S/4HANA (CDS DCLs) is not applied. Therefore, authorization must be designed and enforced within SAC.

 

Authorization Concept for Import Models

When working with SAC Import Models, authorization is handled as follows:

Layer

Responsibility

SAP S/4HANA CDS

Defines which data is extracted

SAC Model

Enforces row-level data authorization

SAC Story

Automatically respects model-level security

Key points to note:
  • CDS DCLs are evaluated only at data extraction time
  • SAC Data Access Control (DAC) governs user visibility
  • Story designers do not need to manage authorization logic
Example Used in This Blog

The same example is used consistently throughout the blog.

Attribute

Value

Authorization Dimensions

Company Code, Plant

Sample Company Code

0100

Sample Plant

RA01, RA02, …

SAC Connection Type

Import

Source System

SAP S/4HANA CDS View

 

Step-by-Step Authorization Setup

Step 1: Prepare CDS View in SAP S/4HANA

Ensure that the CDS View contains the fields required for authorization, i.e., Company Code and Plant.

Example CDS Used:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZCDEMO002V'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Demo Authorization Consumption VIew'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Analytics.query: true
@VDM.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
define view ZC_DEMO_AUTH_2
  as select from ZI_DEMO_AUTH_1
{
  PurchaseOrder,
  PurchaseOrderItem,
  PurchaseOrderCategory,
  CompanyCode, // Authorization field
  Plant,       // Authorization Field
  @Semantics.currencyCode: true
  DocumentCurrency,
  @DefaultAggregation: #SUM
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'DocumentCurrency'
  PurOrderNetAmount
}

Important notes:

  • Authorization-relevant fields must be part of the CDS output
  • CDS DCLs are not used for runtime authorization in SAC Import Models

 

Step 2: Create Import Model in SAP Analytics Cloud

  • Navigate to Connections in SAC.
  • Create an SAP S/4HANA Import Connection.
  • Import the CDS View as a Model.

  • At this stage, the data is physically stored in SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Step 3: Enable Data Access Control (DAC)

  • Open the imported Model
  • Navigate to Settings
  • Navigate to Model Preferences
  • Enable Data Access Control

  • This step activates row-level authorization for the model.

 

Step 4: Mark Authorization-Relevant Dimensions

  • Enable data access control for the required dimensions.
  • Select CompanyCode, and Plant.

  • These dimensions are now evaluated during data access.

 

Step 5: Create Data Access Roles

  • Navigate to Security → Data Access
  • Create a new Data Access Role

  • Provide Role information, Role template, and review before creating. Template helps to create roles fast for general sections like BI Admin or Planner. In this we will choose template as ‘Blank’.

  • After role is created, we will move to ‘Select Model’, choose your import model.

  • Select dimensions required for authorizations and provide values for each.

 

Step 6: Assign Data Access Role to Users

  • Navigate to Security → Roles
  • Select the relevant user
  • Assign Business Role – SAC_ROLE_DEMO_001 to users for Row-level authorization.
  • The user now inherits Company Code and Plant restrictions.

 

Step 7: Validate Authorization in SAC Story

  • Create or open a Story based on the model.
  • Add a table or chart in story for validation.
  • Include Company Code and Plant as dimensions.
  • Authorization is automatically enforced at runtime.

 

Results

After completing the setup:

  • Data visibility is restricted at row level.
  • A single Story can be reused for multiple user groups.
  • No duplication of Stories or Models is required.
  • Authorization is centrally managed in SAC.
  • Import performance remains unchanged.

 

Best Practices

  • Enable Data Access Control immediately after model creation.
  • Use consistent authorization dimensions across models.
  • Follow clear and business-aligned naming conventions for roles.
  • Do not rely on CDS DCLs for Import Model security.
  • Always validate authorization using multiple test users.

 

Conclusion

When working with SAP Analytics Cloud Import Models based on SAP S/4HANA CDS Views, authorization must be implemented within SAC.

By using:

  • Data Access Control
  • Authorization-enabled dimensions
  • Data Access Roles

you can achieve secure, scalable, and reusable Story-level authorization based on Company Code and Plant fully aligned with standard SAP practices.
